This is the logo my collaborator Saul Schleimer and I add onto our models. It is a 2-dimensional stylised picture of the Whitehead link, a key example from our research area, 3-dimensional geometry and topology. It also resembles our initials!

These are the files that I reverse engineered from the original prop of DR1 used in filming the web series Rotor DR1. Rotor DR1 is a series that takes place in a post-apocalyptic world, where half of the population is either dead or missing. A virus has taken over, and only one in ten people who come in contact with it survive. The skies are filled with autonomous drones and the show’s protagonist, Kitch, is a 16-year-old boy who, with his drone companion DR1, sets out to find his father who may or may not still remain alive. Check out the Rotor DR1 series, and website here:
www.rotordr1.com Electronic Kit available at:
www.flitetest.com
http://store.flitetest.com/electrohub-tricopter-kit/ Read the story of the collaboration between StoneKap Productions/Flite Test and 3-D Legion, LLC here:
http://3dprint.com/47841/rotor-dr1-3d-printed-drones/ 3-D Legion, LLC website:
http://www.the3dlegion.com/

ROTOR DR1 Parts List and 3D Print Setup
(Please contact Flite Test to purchase the electronic components if you plan to fly your DR1 kit) All parts are designed to be 3D printed on a minimu
m build volume of 6.125” x 6.125” x 6.125” Will pri
nt on any MakerBot Replicator (except Mini Replicator)
, XYZ Printing DaVinci 1.0, Robo 3D R1 Printer and
many others. Check your 3D printer build volume pri
or to printing. DO NOT SCALE PARTS! Parts can be printed in ABS, or
PLA filaments. Some printed parts may require
clean up. Such include needle nose pliers, sandpape
r, and a Dremel tool to remove overhang, and
supports. Using a dual head extruder and dissolvable filament will
reduce clean up of parts. You can print in any color(s), colors listed
below are recommended, but notnecessary. It is at your discretion to build parts with, or without supports. Please keep in mind, there will be necessary clean up of parts either way.
Speed, resolution of parts, infill settings, the us
e of rafts, and/or supports, will determine how lon
g each print will take. You will need:
Screwdriver
Sandpaper
Needle Nose Pliers (for removing support material)
Super Glue or similar strong bonding adhesive
Dremel Tool (Use as needed) Hardware:
(x6) #4-40 x ¾” Long Screws for Body Connecting Arm
s, Landing feet, Connecting Standoffs (x6) #4-40 Hex Nuts for Body Connecting Arms, Landing feet, Connecting Standoffs (x6) #3-24 x 3/8” Screw (for Plastic) for Propeller Housing and Main Body Assembly (x2) #4 Screws to attach Outrigger support legs from underside Optional Build Hardware:
For a more realistic look, you may print the body and propeller housings without the faux rivets, and use actual rivets. Optional build requires:
(x50) 1/8” Blind Rivets (x6) #3-24 x 3/8” Screw (for Plastic) for Propeller
Housing and Main Body Assembly (x2) #4 Screws to attach Outrigger support legs from underside 1.) Rotor DR1 Main Body Top (x1)

comments.text:
Parts are very nice for 3d models but many are going to be difficult to print, lots of supports needed think they could have been made more printer friendly, cant see what orientation to print some of them especially in ABS, take a small item like the camera how do you print it? I tried in orientation shown but no luck, was thinking about cutting it in half and printing it flat then glue halves together.
Some of the big parts are going to need lots of supports.
This project is would be ideal for dual extruder machines with water solvable filament.
comments.author: xairflyer

comments.text:
These were all printed with a single extruder. Some clean up is required per the instructions printed. This is a vid of a fan that utilized my design and 3D printed without issues. See YouTube vid here:
https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=dRh8MiLMEvw&feature=youtu.be
comments.author: xairflyer

comments.text: Thanks Xairflyer, all prints were tested personally on 4 of the 3D printers I own for my business. These were designed to be 3D printed friendly for anyone with a minimum 6-1/4" square 3D printer. I will post a illustration of the orientation of parts to show printer friendly views. The camera is easily printed without supports flat bottom up. The only parts that would require supports are the arms and legs.
comments.author: xairflyer

comments.text:
Thankyou for taking time to reply, You mention a Da Vinci printer I have the 1.0A I would really appreciate the best orientations.
I can see now that the camera has a flat back, and could be printed that way, but I cant see how the the main body top can be printed with the three internal tabs sticking out and no supports, also the battery cover would require supports if printed on either its top or back
comments.author: cstarrman

comments.text: There are instructions I provided that recommend supports or not for all parts. I designed parts to be 3D printer friendly. Those internal tabs will have some sag on the underside, which you can't see when assembled. I have printed several complete sets.

description.text: This is a fully customizable, easy to print Gyro. The customizer code is optimized to generate the design really fast! It also makes use of a new customizer feature for setting slider widget step size. I also commented the script really thoroughly, so this should be useful if you are learning to write OpenSCAD code. Thanks to althepal for his design, which I studied before designing my own. slo-mo video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lXOnPqXsElE

This will print with no supports, it will never have > 45 degree overhangs For small gyros, I print without infill so they print faster (the one in the photo printed in 1 hour). for larger gyros, consider doing one or more of the following:
  • turning up the infill percentage
  • turn up the number of shells
  • increase the height of the gyro
  • increase the thickness of the rings
    • all of these options make the rings stiffer which helps them not fall apart at larger diameters

comments.text:
Hello atartanian,
My name is Dave Bahr and I'm a middle school special education teacher here in Oregon. I've printed nearly 70 (yes seventy!) of these customized versions for my students, many of whom have ADHD, behavioral needs, or are cognitively delayed in many regards. I've found these to be a great alternative and tool for students to help them focus in classes by keeping their hands busy allowing their brains to focus on the lesson at hand. I've found it also stimulates left-brain right-brain interactions further increasing attention and retention in classes. Teachers have unsolicitedly commented on how these once distracted learners are able to more fully participate in classes and discussions with less talking, pencil tapping, or walking around the room than ever before.
I'm writing to seek your permission in making these widely available to other teachers and students by posting these on an etsy site. If willing, I'd be forever grateful and would of course provide credit to the original creator (you).
Feel free to post a response on here or email me directly at [email protected] .

description.text:
Made some small changes to incorporate a smart lcd controller into the lid of the box. This resulted in a slightly longer box. Incorporated fan mounts for (2) 40MM fans. I have not yet printed this box entirely, but have printed some test lids and the original box for purposes of test fitting and improving the design. This print is very challenging in ABS as the layers tend to want to delaminate even when printing in an enclosure. Updates:
  • 05/02/2015: Got both sides printed and realized during assembly that the fans will have to be reduced for clearance with the LCD and I completely forgot to add holes for electronics from the RAMBo board. Box isn't tall enough either to clear the wiring and connectors of the LCD panel. Back to the drawing board.

title: Case for Pi 2/B+ w/ Adafruit PiTFT

description.text:
A compact case for a Pi 2 or Pi B+ with the Adafruit 2.8" PiTFT resistive touch screen.
https://www.adafruit.com/products/1601 The case includes access for all cables and ports, including routing the camera cable out any of 3 sides.

Print both halves. (the upper half needs to be flipped before slicing)  
Attach the PiTFT board to the upper half using standard computer screws (such as used for mounting harddrives).  
Attach the Pi B+ board to the bottom using similar screws.  
Align the board connectors and snap the two halves together. It is easiest to close the end opposite the USB ports first and work your way toward the USB/Ethernet ports.

This is the Gemini capsule and service modules from the 1960's program that let us learn everything we needed to know for the Apollo program. I found the basic model in sketchup from the Trimble site (http://sketchup.google.com/3dwarehouse/details?mid=13ddfafa0b41d8f77550eb58de5306fc&prevstart=48). The model does not have the kind of detail I would like for printing but unlike many of the other models I found it was actually round as opposed to faceted. At some point I may go back and add some raised lines to show the segments, hatches, panels and attitude jets. But for now this is enough to impress most passers by! Enjoy!

I had to rescale the imported model to 60% to fit on my platform I used the following settings. I wanted to print it quick just to see if it would work at all. Layer 0.34
Fill 5%
Shells 3
Supports : on It filled with support material behind the back of the spacecraft as that part is concave. You might not need this but I was worried it would be too hard to bridge. I stopped the print just after the little side "vents" finised on the service module and switched from white to black.

I camp, hike, and tailgate, a lot. And I do not like having many condiment shakers to haul around. This useful dodecahedron shaker consists of ten compartments all utilizing a water bottle neck, thread, and cap. Eight of the compartments are slightly larger than the volume of the cap. But, two of them utilize the internal space inside of the Dodecashaker for, you guessed it, salt and pepper. Each cap can be labeled, and each compartment can be used for other useful storage, such as beads, pills, you name it. Heck, use different color caps and you'll have a mind game trying to remember what's in each. Here are the steps I used to create this cool looking, useful, work of art.
  • 3D print two halves of the dodecahedron, well, half dodecahedron. Print with large opening on top with no support, worked for me.
  • 3D print the spacer.
  • After some sanding, epoxy the spacer to one side of the dodecahedron halves. Ensure you apply epoxy all the way around as this will be your sealing divider.
  • Sand some more to ensure the spacer is flat, epoxy the other half and ensure the two are lined up perfectly. I used a full peanut butter jar to apply weight as they dried and alignment was perfect.
  • Cut the tops off 12 bottles just below the lip or rim. My bottles had a rim of 33mm.
  • Sand each cut edge flat and ensure you expose as much area to sanding as this will help provide a better area for epoxy adhesion.
  • You may need to grind a little on the dodecahedron to clean up the recessed locations.
  • Apply a layer of epoxy to the bottle top flat rim.
  • Insert each into the recessed locations. Turn after you insert to create a perfect layer. You may want to do two at a time, across from each other, and use a clamp to hold firmly until dry.
  • Wait until everything dries, usually 24 hours, and wash thoroughly.
  • Create a stick on label or simply use a maker to mark each cap of its contents.
  • Fill'er up
  • Place your new Dodecashaker on your table during your next game party or tailgate, and it's sure to set you apart from the rest.
    • Enjoy!

This object is made for checking the level on the build platform. It could easy work on most 3D printers, but the default settings is for Makerbot Replicator 2X. You just need to scale it to the build platform size of your 3D printer.
It will also show how good your print will stay on the build platform.
The size is 245mm 150mm 0.2mm.
Scale it to the maximum size your 3D printer can use. Also change the height to what layer size you want to use. ex. if you use 0.3mm layer height then change to that height, so it only put down one layer. If you want to test more layer then just add the height as many layer you want to have. Keep in mind it will take more plastic for every layer you use.

I made this with Autodesk 123D Design. I also made this object for leveling: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:70939 You can also see guides and other help on my wiki+ site
:http://makerbotwiki.com/

description.text:
A deck box designed with a Magic: The Gathering "M" logo that twists and locks to seal the box. This was a fun creation, as I got to design it from the ground up, minus the "M" of course. I learned how to design something so that it can print off and have some moving parts. The supports are a bit of a pain, but once removed, it works great.  
The supports are a bit tricky to remove, but not impossible. I uploaded some images of a print, and included is an image of where the difficult supports lie. The only way I've found is to raise up the logo enough to take the small peg out of the track as seen in the last image, from there you should easily be able to remove the support with just a small tool.

author: bobyboy09

title: #NEPAL3DRELIEF The medical needs of the city Sindhupalchok and Gorkha

description.text:
This 3D model aims to help people to understand the medical needs of the city Sindhupalchok and Gorkha. It is reported that Sindhupalchock had 1 hospital and 6 doctors. Also, Gorkha was reported to have 2 hospitals and 8 doctors. Each city had a population of 287,798 and 288,135. If it is estimated 1% of the entire population of two cities need immediate medical attention, 5600 survivors need the support. If it is estimated 5% of the population need care for the next three months, 28,000 survivors need to see medical staffs periodically. If it is estimated 10% of the survivors need a quick first aid, there are 56,000 patients waiting for the medical care. This is a 3D population model of the number of doctors and the patients. The block of doctor population is in green. Those who need immediate medical attention is in the blocks of red. Those who need periodic medical care for the next three months are in the blocks of orange. Also, those who need to see medical staffs for the quick first aid are in the blocks of yellow. As we can see, the number of domestic doctors compared to the number of patients is out-of-proportion. Both cities Sindhupalchok and Gorkha were extensively exposed to the earthquake. Those cities need immediate and ongoing worldwide medical support to help survivors after the earthquake (source : wikipedia). We need your support and skills! Share your 3D model at 3D printing communities (i.e. Thingiverse) with #NEPAL3DRELIEF Fundraising : http://bit.ly/1PZAcx6
Website : http://bit.ly/1InDbgB

author: jhi0417

description.text: HeroClix Action token by CJ [created on 3DTin]

Just created this filament guide which mounts on top of the ToM, using the screws that hold the back z-rods. (The screws are long enough.)
This is especially useful when you have a filament spool located behind the bot.

The picture shows a less than perfect print on the left and a much better one on the right. The left one was printed as shown. The right one was printed with the long side flat on the build surface. It's best to print this laying down unless you have a bot that's better calibrated than mine. The tall strip isn't very rigid (especially in abs) and you get mush instead of a nice print.

author: grampasso

remixed_from.author: RobertHunt
remixed_from.title: PCB mounting clips for 35mm DIN Rail

description.text: Clips for mounting a BeagleBone Black to standard 35mm DIN rail.

Download and print one of each clip ( bbb_Din_clip_1.stl & bbb_Din_clip_2.stl ) for each BBB. Two different clips are required because the hole spacing is not the same on either end of the board. Use M3 screws to fasten the BBB to the clips and then hang the clips on the rail and snap it in. ( the flexible tabs should be on the bottom ). If you have a M3 tap, chase the holes first to make threading the screws easier.
A single Scad was used to generate both clips by merely changing the required hole spacing. ( the required hole spacing for both clips is in the comments ).
The .dxf file has been modified from the original file that this was remixed from because the overall length was too short. In the process, the DIN rail profile was also eased up a bit to make it easier to snap the clips onto the DIN rail.
Nothing notable regarding slicing or heat settings for print.

author: bobyboy09

title: BMW e34 e36 e38 Fuel Pump Sleeve

description.text:
When upgrading to a higher flow pump (e.g., Walbro, TRE, etc.), or simply replacing the expensive stock pump with any of the myriad of cheap alternatives, you'll likely need a spacing sleeve to adapt the stock pump carrier to the smaller diameter universal pumps and locate it at the proper height. There are several machined aluminum parts available online, but they're quite expensive for what they are (enough to buy 2-3 spools of nylon filament). 3D printing to the rescue!  This sleeve should work on the e36 and e38, but I can only personally vouch for its compatibility with the e34.  
In this role, the part will be submerged in gasoline, so you CANNOT use ABS or PLA! I printed mine with Taulman 618 Nylon at 245C / 70C on an MBI 2X with good results. Support should not be necessary given the shallow overhang angles. The only difference between v1 and v2 is a perimeter recess at the bottom intended to retain a stainless steel hose clamp if you're worried about it working its way off without it.

In this role, the part will be submerged in gasoline, so you CANNOT use ABS or PLA. I printed the one currently working well in my '90 turbo e34 535i using Taulman 618 Nylon on an MBI 2X with the following settings: Extruder: 245C
HBP: 70C covered with blue painter's tape
Slicer: Skeinforge, 3 shells, .25mm layers, 50/100mms

title: ABP Belt Finder - <i>PET bottles will not work!</i>

description.text: Since I posted, I have tested PET bootle plastic and it will curl up at 120C. The search continues though, there maybe something out there that can be used as seamless belt! I have issues with the belts in my Automatic Build Platform. They start nicely but very soon they start bulging up at the seams and affect the shapes of the bottom on prints. In most cases is not that important but sometimes it really screws things up. The belt is made from PET and so are most beverage bottles today. I thought one could find a bottle that has a clean cylindrical middle section (no grooves or reliefs) that was around 90 mm in diameter and make a seamless belt of the section. So in order to start the quest for the perfect bootle (hopefully cheap) and not to be in a supermarket with a caliper (potentially puncturing bottles filled with liquids under pressure) I printed a gauge of sorts in my TOM. Updated the STL file - the original had some 3d text that did not print well.

The bottle should have a clean cylindrical section taller than 100mm and fit snugly in the gauge. I have not found a bottle yet (just tried yesterday at a convenience store near my home) but I found something just under it ( Duane Reed seltzer). I also bought a larger Pepsi bottle to check the belt cutting process.
While the bottle is still full mark the lines at the appropriate places using a permanent pen (I took the liquid out for the picture so the lines are visible). The bottle can be cut with scissors (safer). The belt is thicker than the normal ABP belt so the bottle should have thinner walls. Given that most bottles are made from the same basic starting point (the top part comes finished but the bottom part looks like a thick test tube - in the bottling plant a machine heats the piece and expands it to the customers bottle shape) one should look for tall bottles (less material for the wall thus thinner). Cover the belt in Kapton tape for better adhesion.
The wider bottles produce belts that would need an extra roller (or 2) in the ABP to tension it. There is space on the back of it. That is another project in itself.
I will keep my gauge in the car and take it with me when grocery shopping in the QUEST FOR THE PERFECT BOTTLE :)

comments.text: I'd have thought the bottles will be too thick in cross section, certainly all the ones I've sliced up over the years making water rockets seemed too sturdy to make a good conveyor belt. Also beware that beverage bottles usually have multiple co=polymers or coatings to improve fizz-retention and reduce transfer of chemicals into the contents (they're only mostly PET). Any of those additions may not react to ABP temperatures in a good / predictable way.

comments.text: I was also concerned with the thickness but the temperature was my undoing. You've predicted the outcome of the experiment.

author: dan_d_builder

description.text:
This was originally a post from my website since not a lot of people go there I decided to post this here as well go to jimothysquid.weebly.com for all my creation.
I had a tough time deciding whether or not to extruded up or down when making this. I decided to go with up because (and hear me out) you and easily color the dividing lines if they are sticking out. If your printer has multiple filament chambers you probably already know what to do to get the colors different on the board but for everyone who has a single chamber. That means only one color filament at a time I suggest using white filament and a black sharpie to color in the black squares.
*This board will probably be one of the ones that gets divided into 16 pieces.

-Jsquid

author: kagedws6

title: H3 gear set with stock ratio (8/49)

description.text: Although I really like the H3 design, I had issues with the gears. They made quite a bit of noise during reverse moves, probably because they don't fit perfectly. Also the gears are a different ratio than the stock gears (9/47). So I replaced them with an involute gearset that has the same ratio as stock (8/49) which has the benefit that you can keep the e steps the same. Also this means the motor will keep the original torque. for a video see http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XvUsqFo-yYY

A simple, spring loaded mini hair claw. The spring and claws can be printed in various color combinations and snap together without the need for glue.

Layout 2 claws and the spring as shown in the picture (use the same file for both claws). The claws need support material, but it is easily picked off once printed.  
To assemble put one side of the spring through the grip of one of the claws and push it into the slot; it should clip in. Then put the other side though the other claws grip and clip it into the slot

title: Arm Rest Door Handle for International Scout 80/800

description.text:
This is an arm rest style interior door handle for the International Scout 80, 800, 800a and 800b.  
The original had a metal core wrapped in high density foam and leather pattern vinyl. These are nearly impossible to find in good condition today.

Print with support enabled, but do not rotate the model to lay flat on the bed, this will ensure no supports are needed in the visible areas of the arm rest.  
I print them with 0.15mm layers, 4 perimeters and 8 top and bottom solid layers. 15% infill.  
Attach to the door using 1/4"x1-1/4" self tapping sheet metal screws with pan or round heads.

text = Kole`s Drank

Introducing iMacerslide.  I needed to move my iMac to the back of the desk in order to free up some desk space.  So I decided to use Makerslide to create my desk stand.  Very simple design.  Nothing complicated here.   
The file "iMac Stand Front" is a cover for the front of the 3/4 inch plywood.  I used this part as a way to level the stand.  Then I covered it with a piece of angled aluminum and added a brushed finish.

Cut a piece of 3/4 inch plywood to suit your desk.  
Cut a piece of a Makerslide extrusion to suit your piece of plywood.  
Using a laser cutter, cut the two pieces in the file iMac Bezel Outline.  
Print the file "Makerslide" (end stops) x 2  
Add end stops to Makerslide  
Attach the Makerslide to the piece of wood.  
Add a Makerslide carriage to the Makerslide.  
Attach the carriage to the iMac Bezel using bolts or machine screws.  
Cover your screws with a piece of felt as to not scratch your iMac.  
Print the "iMac Stand Front" if needed and attach the Aluminum angle iron to the printed part using glue or epoxy.   
Place your iMac on the Stand and slide it to and fro

description.text: I needed a case for this camera so I could mount it on my Lumenier QAV400. Unfortunately, the only case that size I could find was on eBay for some stupid high price. I'm not very good with CAD, so what I ended up doing was using a design by "Gigahurtz" found here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:548679 I pretty much just sized it to fit a 38x38 board. Then I slimmed down the mount and sized the mount screw holes down to 35mm apart which fit perfectly on the QAV400. I did not use the back cover from this design as it didn't work for this camera. Instead, I used a back cover designed by "ulli62" found here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:720549 I sized it to fit the casing perfectly.
I printed mine with PLA and 100% infill.

Based on the Bionicle symbol for Takanuva, created by Christian Faber.

Tulpa (Tibetan: སྤྲུལ་པ, Wylie: sprul-pa; Sanskrit: निर्मित nirmita and निर्माण nirmāṇa; "to build" or "to construct") also translated as "magical emanation", "conjured thing" and "phantom" is a concept in mysticism of a being or object which is created through sheer spiritual or mental discipline alone.  
As the Tibetan use of the tulpa concept is described in the book Magical Use of Thoughtforms, the student was expected to come to the understanding that the tulpa was just a hallucination. While they were told that the tulpa was a genuine deity, "The pupil who accepted this was deemed a failure – and set off to spend the rest of his life in an uncomfortable hallucination."  
In Jewish folklore, a golem (/ˈɡoʊləm/ goh-ləm; Hebrew: גולם‎) is an animated anthropomorphic being, magically created entirely from inanimate matter. The word was used to mean an amorphous, unformed material (usually out of stone and clay) in Psalms and medieval writing.  
Neurons are powerful, no?

comments.text: Looks cool! Quick question:  from QGIS to Meshlab, what was the general workflow?
comments.author: lmgreco

comments.text:
In general, a terrible mishmash of duct tape and bailing wire. Visit USGS NED and download small scale orthoimagery (*.img at 1/9 arcsecond for best detail). Drag the files into QGIS. You will also need some satellite views, because elevation datasets are hard to figure out where you are.
I then used gdal_translate to extract, convert, and save the data. Something like:
gdal_translate -a_nodata 0 -projwin -92.1900414739 35.9819798964 -92.1151227387 35.9382566605 -of XYZ -a_ullr 0 4791 6798 0 C:/Users/jcste_000/Downloads/n36w093/imgn36w093_13.img "C:/Users/jcste_000/Documents/Mapping projects/sylamore25k-scaled.xyz"
I then changed the extension from "xyz" to "asc" (ascii triples) because "XYZ" means something else to Meshlab. Import the "asc" file, re-scale if desired, and export as an STL or OBJ. Import into Meshmixer and extrude a bottom and rescale.
comments.author: lmgreco

comments.text: Thanks!  I might give this a shot.  Your terrain really has some nice detail.

remixed_from.title: Active Cooling Fan Duct v2 for Replicator 1 / Duplicator 4 / FlashForge / CTC

title: MEGAMOUTH COOLING FAN for Replicator 1 / Duplicator 4 / FlashForge / CTC / Monoprice! (REMIXED from Active Cooling Fan V2 by thruit00!)

description.text:
READ FIRST/DISCLAIMER: The goal of this design was to optimize cooling performance at all cost! That being said, you may need to remove the front panel of your printer. I'm using the Monoprice printer, which is similar to the Creator X, and I had to remove the front sound insulating panel. You might be thinking like "ehh..." now, but don't listen to yourself...just think, would you rather have beauty contest printer or beast mode printer?...that's a rhetorical question. This is my mod on the amazing Active Cooling Fan Duct v2 by thruit00! I really like the design, but I felt like I needed even more air...or maybe I wasn't using the right fan? Anyways, I made an adapter that attaches a blower fan onto thruit00's design because there's no such thing as overkill. About this design:
After testing many blower fans of different sizes and iterating the design many times, I realized that for the effort I was putting in, I better get some insane air flow or it wouldn't be worth it. Let's just say that when the fan is on, your extruder temperature should drop by about 5 degrees. As it is said in the ancient proverb, go big or go home. Parts you'll need:
  • Print 1x Megamouthcut.stl, 2x ActiveDuctV2.0_Clip.stl, 1x blower_adapter.stl (print this last part with support)
  • 2x M3x12 countersunk head screws (borrowed from Active Cooling Fan V2)
  • 2x M3x16 countersunk head screws (borrowed from Active Cooling Fan V2)
  • 6x M3 nuts (4 from the Active Cooling Fan, and 2 more for this adapter)
  • 2X M3x35 (for the adapter)
  • Purchase the blower fan http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00B2ARV22/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
  • 12V power supply like this one http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B006NTNGN0/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1 or wire it directly to the printer's control board somehow
    • Instructions:
  • Screw everything together
  • Remove the front panel or do whatever you need to do to make room for this fan assembly
  • Optional: you may need to raise the temperature settings by 5 degrees to compensate for the intense air flow
  • Begin print, turn on fan after the 1st layer
If you're having trouble printing the blower_adapter.STL with support because the support keeps breaking off the bed, try rotating the part 90 degrees along the Z axis.

title: Telescoping Tubes
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Inspired by extending tubes (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7081).
I wanted to use less material, make each tube thinner so more will fit in the same area and have the tubes lock in place when open or closed. When the tubes are closed the guides that protrude into the track of the tube around it are held in place by a bump in the track (like in thing #1481).
When the tubes are open they twist to lock and the guides go over another bump in the track so it can't fall back. Having it twist to lock allows the track wall so it can resist force along the axis.

Your printer will need to be fairly well calibrated to print these. I suggest starting with the "2 small tubes.stl" because it is quick to print and doesn't take much plastic if it doesn't work. If you are feeling more confident you can print the larger tubes.
The largest tube looks most like a telescope, it starts off at 60mm and extends to about 258mm. Once it printed you may need to use a knife to break the strings between the tubes and give the tubes a slight squeeze to break the guides from the tracks. I have included the source files created in NX6. If you can edit them all of the parameters are east to change to change the tube dimensions or add more tubes.

title: ZelosLaser Cutter 2.0 : Open Source, Sturdy & Versatile

description.text:
The Open Source ZelosLaser Cutter V2 is a full working unit to engrave and even cut material like plastics, wood, leather and much more. It is easy to build and has a number of exclusive features that cannot be found on other engraver machines. If you build one, please share a picture! :) Lets Engrave : ZelosDynamics Logo on Plywood
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hhykOXjyOjY follow us to stay on top
++ TWITTER ++ http://goo.gl/zdG9zz
++ FACEBOOK ++ http://goo.gl/NMz1As

ZelosLaser is the world’s first, high stable and completely open-source laser cutter and engraver. It has been designed to be sturdy, affordable and versatile. As open-source technology, we are also offering a number of documentation online for its design and implementation. Easy to build in under 4-5 Hours! follow us to stay on top
++ TWITTER++ http://goo.gl/zdG9zz
++ FACEBOOK ++ http://goo.gl/NMz1As

Qty Part Name
5x Aluminium profile 20x20 Type B 15cm
4x Aluminium profile 20x20 Type B 30cm
4x Aluminium profile 20x20 Type B 40cm
8x Screws M2.5x15 (Wood version
13x -M3 Allen SCREW M3x10
6x -M3 Allen SCREW M3x16
12x -M3 Allen SCREW M3x20
5x -M3 Allen SCREW M3x25
89x -M4 Allen SCREW M4x8
14x -M4 Allen SCREW M4x20
89x washers M4 wide Brim
24x nuts M3 Normal
8x M3 lock nut
20x M4 Normal Nut
96x M4 threaded plate M4 1x GT2 Timing Belt 57CM
2x GT2 Timing Belt 87CM
2x GT2 Timing Belt 158mm Closed Loop
3x Timing Pulley GT2 20 teeth, 5mm Bore
4x Timing Pulley GT2 20 teeth, 8mm Bore
1x Steel Rod 8mm diameter 29,5cm
2x Steel Rod 8mm diameter 29CM
2x Steel Rod 8mm diameter 42CM
6x LM8UU linear bearings
3x 608z bearings
1x MDF Wood Base Plate 28x32 / 7mm thin
1x Laser protective glasses
3x Nema 17 stepper motor 36oz
1x Arduino Uno R3 or clone
1x GRBL-Shield
2x Pololu a4988 Stepper Driver
1x Power Supply 12V / 4A
2x 12V fan 4x4cm
2x Power Switch
1x Laser protective glasses
1x Laser Module 445nm 2watt M140 diode Copper Modules With Leads & Three Element Glass Lens
1x Laser Driver 3A 450nm TTL
4x Endstops
2x handholds
1x Various cable, different plugs ...
1x 3D PRINTED PARTS Tools you need
Allen Key M4
plier screwdriver
screwdriver
a brush or something similar
Metalsaw when the steel rods or aluminum profiles are not even cut when you buy it.
Jigsaw when the base plate has not been cut when buying some wood glue (to glue a thin layer of cork on the bottom plate)

BUILD IT
Begin with the aluminum profiles. screwed all together like in the Images.
Do not forget to push enogh M4 threaded plates into the V-slot of the profile.

Baseplate
glue the cork to the bottom plate as in the photos.
use a brush or similar to remove all the small blisters. Turn around the bottom plate and put some weight on it. Wait until the glue is dry.

Attach the handholds and Baseplate to the Frame
Attach the handholds with 4x - M4x20 screws.
Attach the Base Plate with the printed Holders.

Prepare the axis
Sliding/push the LM8UU linear bearings on the Steel Rods.
Attach the steel rods to the chassis.
fix the carriage to the linear bearings with cable ties.

Electronics/wiring Wiring Diagram for 2watt Laser
For the wiring we use a very reinforced system.
it is very easy to build and works great. -If you want to use two motors with two Stepper Driver for Y axis, you can "clone" any axis for use two motors and two drivers for a single axis. The CNC shield is capable of it
Check this for more CNC shield infos.
http://blog.protoneer.co.nz/arduino-cnc-shield-v3-00-assembly-guide/ Don´t connect the laser before adjust the power on the laser driver.

SOFTWARE
Before you can start you need the Arduino IDE, available on their webpage.
Arduino IDE http://www.arduino.cc/en/main/Software

Modified firmware for the Arduino UNO R3 or similar clone:
http://www66.zippyshare.com/v/2N7UjyV3/file.html
GRBL0.9i_Library_zelosLaserengraverV2.zip (Modified for Version 2.0 ZelosLaser Cutter with 2 Axis) Grbl wiki: github.com/grbl/grbl/wiki

drawing software: Inkscape 0.91/combined with a laser engraver plug-in.
https://inkscape.org/de/
( we use @now the one Plugin from the Microsclice Engraver. We are working on our own plugin)

Grbl needs G-Code.
http://reprap.org/wiki/G-code We need another Program to send the G-Code to the Arduino UNO R3 board. Grbl Controller 3.0 by Zapmaker http://zapmaker.org/projects/grbl-controller-3-0/ ############################################# NOTE: Before starting, make sure that any older installation of Grbl has been completely removed from the Arduino IDE. Download the Modified Grbl source code (v0.9i) Once downloaded, unzip it and you'll have a folder called grbl-master or something similar. Make sure you are using the most recent version of the Arduino IDE (last tested on v1.61). Load Grbl into the Arduino IDE as a Library. Launch the Arduino IDE. Click the Sketch drop-down menu, navigate to Include Library, and click Add .ZIP Library, note that this still works with a folder (prior to IDE version 1.6.2 this will be Import Library..., and click Add Library...). Select the Grbl folder inside the grbl-master folder when asked to select a library folder you'd like to add. The correct folder only contains the source files and an example directory.It may take a few seconds for the Arduino IDE to import it. NOTE: For pre-v1.05 Arduino IDE users, you will need to manually add Grbl into your Arduino libraries, so that it will appear in the Import Library... menu. Search the internet for how to install, then skip to step 4. Open the GrblUpload Arduino example. Click the File down-down menu, navigate to Examples->Grbl, and select GrblUpload. Compile and upload Grbl to your Arduino. Connect your Arduino Uno to your computer. Make sure your board is set to the Arduino Uno in the Tool->Board menu and the serial port is selected correctly in Tool->Serial Port. Click the Upload, and Grbl should compile and flash to your Arduino! (Flashing with a programmer also works by using the Upload Using Programmer menu command.) Once you have your Grbl library set up in the Arduino IDE, you can update, replace, or modify the Grbl source code in the library folder. On a Mac, it's located in ~/Documents/Arduino/libraries/. On Windows, it's in My Documents\Arduino\libraries. You may need to restart the Arduino IDE for this change to take effect. No fuss! No muss! https://github.com/grbl/grbl/wiki/Compiling-Grbl I hope you guys like the tutorial.
many greetings,
Zelos-Dynamics

description.text:
This is to display the album art of the record you are currently playing on your record player.  It is designed to be mounted with a medium 3M command strip (no holes, apartment safe!) and the main body of the display slides over the mounting bracket to hide the command strip's pull tab.  
EDIT: I added an updated version that hangs a little further out from the wall to better accommodate bigger gatefold record jackets.

After printing, place command strip on the smaller side of the mounting bracket (smaller piece).  
Attach command strip and mounting bracket to wall  
Slide main body over the mounting bracket so that it covers the command strip tab.  
Spin some records and enjoy your rotating wall art.

title: Rotating Car iPod Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Using velcro or adhesive under the stand, you can stick this iPod stand to your car dashboard. The pivot block tilts up or down, accommodating sloped dashboards. You can turn the rotator plate to switch between portrait and landscape orientations for your iPod.
NOTE: This is a work in progress. While these parts are all technically printable without support, some are too large to currently fit on the Makerbot's 4X4 build platform. I plan on eventually redesigning the front slider plate and rotator plate to accommodate these current build size limitations.

Print the front slider plate with the chamfered side down and the grooved side facing up.
Print the pivot block with its squeeze tab hole facing up.
Print the rotator plate with the back surface facing down.
Print the rotator squeeze tab with either flat face facing down (should look like an H letter from above).
Print the stand with the front surface facing down. It should look like a U from above. Apply velcro or adhesive to the bottom of the stand. If using velcro, apply the hooks to the car dash and the hoops to the stand. Lay the stand down on a stable surface (should look like a U from above. Carefully (watching out for pinch points) press the pivot block in between the prongs of the stand, aligning the large conical holes of the pivot block with the large cones of the stand. This may require a LOT of force, as the stand prongs were designed to be very sturdy. Pivot the pivot block until the smaller cones lock into any of the smaller conical holes on the pivot block. Press the rear end of the rotator squeeze tabs into the pivot block. Then press the front end of the rotator squeeze tabs into the grooved hole of the rotator plate. Place your iPod in the rotator plate. Slide the front slider plate onto the rotator plate, securing the iPod in place.

comments.text: The 1st revision of the rotator squeeze tabs works, but only if you file down the teeth enough to let them squeeze into the hole of the pivot block.
comments.author: CDavis

comments.text: I have now uploaded the third revision parts, for your downloading pleasure. The pivot block, rotator plate, and stand have all been updated. I have also introduced a new part: Rotator Squeeze Tabs. This new part has significant strength improvement over the previous design (it prints in an orientation that allows for greater bending flexibility and prevents brittle fractures).

title: Everyday Carry Credit Card Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my take on a compact credit card case for lightweight everyday carry.  
A traditional wallet is thick because of the layers of fabric and leather between the cards.  I designed this case after trying other printable wallets that left the edges of the cards exposed.  That made my paper cards curl and fray at the edges.  I wanted them to be better protected, and for the wallet to have a cleaner appearance.  
This wallet is made of two identical sides that are symmetrical, so that they nestle together.  The corners and sides act like a hinge and keep the cards contained when you open one side to select a card from within.  The design expands from about six to twelve cards.  I like to throw a credit-card pocket tool inside when I don't want to carry a separate pocket knife. A simple rubber band or hair band holds the wallet closed, and serves as a money clip. 
Update 2016 Sep 30:  STL file has been updated to fix structural errors.

Best strength for the teeth is achieved by using small layer heights for a greater extrusion width-to-height ratio.  I used .15mm layers.   
Make sure you have good bed adhesion to keep the print from curling.  Set your slicer to add a brim if you have a problem.   
You may scale the design vertically to accommodate more or fewer cards if you need.

author: lorenmcconnell

title: Ekobots - Table Fix and Join for Mendel Prusa.

description.text:
Table Fix and Table Join for Mendel Prusa. For use with PCB 214mm x 214mm x ~2mm
and glass 214mm x 200mm x 2mm. I created and added a join for 2 tables,
you do not need it for a single table,
files: table_fix_TJ.stl and table_fix_BJ.stl You can help me to do more things like this.
Buy my designs at pinshape:http://pinshape.com/users/27920-jsirgado
The OpenSCAD file is there, you can change all.

Use 3mm screws, nuts and washers.
In the centre hole use a minimum of 40mm height screw + coil.
In the other holes use a 20mm screw. If you use the table_screw_fix, use glue to fix the nut in it. I created and added a join for 2 tables, but just for configurable printers with correct electronics.
For it you can use 2x glass 214mm x 200mm x 2mm or
1x glass 428mm x 200mm x 2mm.
If you know a electronic solution for 2 or more PCB beds for a standard board please tell us. For all configurations I recommend use "Kapton Tape" on the glass in the PCB side and a "Glass Wool" under the PCB. You do not need kapton tape over the glass in the print area.
With a brush, use a magic portion (50% water and 50% white glue).
No toxic, easy to use and clean,
but please... DO IT BEFORE HEAT THE BED. 1 - The tape will protect you from glass shard and the PCB from the glass. And the surface of the table will have more homogeneous temperature.
2 - The glass wool will save the printer electronics, money, electricity and the planet.
